channel.title: Text Machine Lab
channel.description: Recent content on Text Machine Lab

item.description: Be on the lookout for our tutorial on the dataset explosion in QA, NLI, and commonsense reasoning, accepted to COLING 2020! This will be both a guide for practitioners who just want to grab and use smth, and a survey of the latest techniques for future datasets
The next Clinical Natural Language Processing Workshop will be held at EMNLP 2020. Submission deadline: August 15, 2020.
We are organizing a new EMNLP 2020 workshop Insights from Negative results from NLP. Invited talks by Rada Mihalcea and Byron Wallace! Special focus: breaking pre-trained meaning representations.

The 2nd International Summer School for Conversational Intelligence (CISS 2019) will be held at UMass Lowell, June 24-29, 2019. Free to qualifying students! Registration opens Feb 15, 2019. Qualifying round begins Feb 25, 2019. Qualifying round ends Mar 25, 2019.
The next Clinical Natural Language Processing Workshop will be held at NAACL 2019. Submission deadline: Mar 6, 2019.
Text Machine Lab is organizing a SemEval-2017 task Normalization of Medical Concepts in Clinical Narrative (Task 11). Help spread the word!
LREC 2018 Tutorial: Distributional compositional semantics in the age of word embeddings: tasks, resources and methodology.
Text Machine Lab is hiring! Two PhD positions open, available immediately.
We are a hosting site for for the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad (NACLO)

We are going to serve as a hosting site for for the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad (NACLO). Please register to participate by 1 pm EST on January 25, 2017. Check out time, location, and other details.
We are organizing a workshop on Clinical Natural Language Processing at COLING 2016. Submission deadline is September 25, 2016. Please submit your work!

Jun 2016. Text Machine Lab is organizing a SemEval-2017 task #HashtagWars: Learning a Sense of Humor (Task 6). Training data for the task was released on September 5, 2016. Evaluation will start on January 9, 2017. Please register to participate!

Text Machine Lab's system for measuring semantic similarity of text (SimiHawk) placed 7th out of 119 systems submitted to the Semantic Textual Similarity task in SemEval 2016 (Task 1), placing our team 6th out of 43 participating teams. Congrats to Peter Potash, Alexey Romanov, and Willie Boag!

Text Machine Lab's system for Twitter sentiment analysis (TwitterHawk) takes 1st place in SemEval2015 Task 10C (Topic-Based Message Polarity Classification). Congrats to William Boag and Peter Potash!
CliNER system for clinical named entity recognition released @2014 i2b2/UTHealth Shared-Tasks and Workshop on Challenges in Natural Language Processing for Clinical Data.
LREC 2014 Tutorial: Deep Semantic Annotation with Shallow Methods.
Dagstuhl seminar on Computational Models of Language Meaning in Context.

Hi! I am an undergraduate Electrical Engineering/Computer Science double major at Text Machine Lab, University of Massachusetts Lowell. My current work focuses on using Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) models to plan and generate natural language. As a side project I have been creating models for dialogue generation.
Hi, I'm a sophomore studying Computer Science at UMass Lowell. I am currently interning at the Text Machine Laboratory.

Greetings! this is the webpage of Matthew Downey. Currently I am a Mechanical Engineering student persuing minor in Computer Science, going into my sophmore year at Umass Lowell. Interning in the text Machine Lab, I assist the researchers with their projects. Along with this, I study ML and its use in NLP.
Hello! I graduated from the University of Massachusetts Lowell with a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science with a focus on Data Science…. «» lol

Hi! I am an intern at Text Machine Lab, University of Massachusetts Lowell. I am studying to become a data scientist. Beyond taking programming and statistics courses, my goal is to learn machine learning with Python.

item.title: NarrativeTime: Order and Timing of Events in Narrative Text
item.description: This project has two stages so far: (1) We propose to use a set of simple, uniform in architecture LSTM-based models to recover different kinds of temporal relations from text. Using the shortest dependency path between entities as input, the same architecture is implemented to extract intra-sentence, cross- sentence, and document creation time relations. A “double-checking” technique reverses entity pairs in classification, boosting the recall of positive cases and reducing misclassifications between opposite classes.

item.title: Normalization of Medical Concepts in Clinical Narrative
item.description: Normalization maps clinical terms in medical notes to concepts in standardized medical vocabularies. To complement the traditional lexical transformation based approach, we propose a hybrid normalization system which incorporates a deep learning model to capture semantic similarity between different surface expressions of the same concept. When evaluating our system against the mentions which may be normalized to existing concepts in the ShARe/CLEF eHealth 2013 dataset, our hybrid system achieves 90.6% in accuracy and outperforms a strong exact match + edit distance baseline by 2.

item.title: Normalization of Relative and Incomplete Temporal Expressions in Clinical Narratives
item.description: @article{sun2015normalization, title={Normalization of relative and incomplete temporal expressions in clinical narratives}, author={Sun, Weiyi and Rumshisky, Anna and Uzuner, Ozlem}, journal={Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association: JAMIA}, volume={22}, number={5}, pages={1001}, year={2015}, publisher={American Medical Informatics Association} }

item.title: PhD student
item.description: Hi! I am a PhD student at Text Machine Lab, University of Massachusetts Lowell. My background is in Applied Mathematics and I currently focus on representation learning problems in ML. My work also includes building NLP models for question answering and analyzing electronic health records.

item.title: PhD student
PhD student
PhD, now at IBM Watson
item.description: My expertise includes Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning, and Data Visualization. My thesis: “Mining the Clinical Narrative: Mortality Prediction and Concept Normalization”.

item.title: PhD, now at Microsoft
item.description: I am currently a fourth year Ph.D. student at UMass Lowell in the Text-Machine Lab working with Anna Rumshisky. My research interests at this moment are particularly focused on applying Deep Learning methods in Natural Language Processing.

item.title: PhD, now at Microsoft Research
item.description: I received a Masters in Mathematics and a PhD in Computer Science. My dissertation focused on deep learning strategies for argument mining. I currently work at MSR Maluuba.

item.title: PhD, now at Nuance
item.description: I am interested in many aspects of natural language processing, deep learning and AI. Currently I work on temporal relation information extraction and coreference resolution. I studied engineering in the past, and was a software engineer before joining the lab. Besides NLP, I also had some experience in speech sysnthesis and computer vision.

item.title: Postdoc
item.description: I am a post-doctoral associate at the Computer Science Department, University of Massachusetts (Lowell). I hold a Ph.D. degree from the Department of Language and Information Sciences at the University of Tokyo (Japan). My research spans the intersection of linguistics, natural language processing, and machine learning. This page lists my work with Text Machine lab, which I joined in 2017. See my full research profile here.

item.title: Resolving Polysemy in Verbs: Contextualized Distributional Approach to Argument Semantics
item.description: @article{rumshisky_resolving_2008, author = “Rumshisky, Anna”, title = “Resolving {Polysemy} in {Verbs}: {Contextualized} {Distributional} {Approach} to {Argument} {Semantics}", abstract = “Natural language is characterized by a high degree of polysemy, and the majority of content words accept multiple interpretations. Native speakers rely on context to assign the correct sense to each word in an utterance. Natural language processing (NLP) applications, such as the automated word sense disambiguation, require the ability to identify correctly context elements that activate each sense.

item.title: Revealing the dark secrets of BERT
RuSentiment: An Enriched Sentiment Analysis Dataset for Social Media in Russian
item.description: We present RuSentiment, a new dataset for sentiment analysis of social media posts in Russian. RuSentiment is currently the largest in its class for Russian, with 30,521 posts annotated with Fleiss’ kappa of 0.58 (3 annotations per post). To diversify the dataset, 6,749 posts were pre-selected with an active learning-style strategy. We report baseline classification results, and we also release the best-performing embeddings trained on 3.2B tokens of Russian VKontakte posts.

item.title: RuSentiment: An Enriched Sentiment Analysis Dataset for Social Media in Russian

item.title: TwitterHawk - a Twitter Sentiment Analysis System
item.description: TwitterHawk is an open-source natural language processing system for Twitter sentiment analysis. This system was developed for the SemEval-2015 Task 10: Sentiment Analysis in Twitter. The system placed 1st in topic-based sentiment classification (Subtask C), and ranked 6th out of 40 in identifying the sentiment of sarcastic tweets (for Subtask B). The system also placed 5th/11 for Subtask A (sentiment of a tweet's sub-phrase), 10th/40 for Subtask B (sentiment of a full tweet), and 3rd/6 for Subtask D (summarization of Subtask C).
